More Notes: A 10% rise in GDP per capita reduces fatalities from floods by around 1.4% at the median value of loss.
A 10% rise in GDP per capita reduces median deaths from tropical cyclones by between 0.5 and 0.7%.
A 10% rise in GDP per capita reduces median deaths from tropical cyclones by between 0.5 and 0.7%.

Deaths are reduced in countries with a better Investment Profile. Investment Profile includes assessments of factors that affect risk to investments, including contract viability, the risk of expropriation, profit repatriation and payment delays.
Deaths from floods are lower in countries with a lower risk of religious tension or religious interference in politics.

The number of deaths is lower in countries with lower risk of military influence in politics and lower risk of external conflict (including external diplomatic and political pressure, such as withholding of aid, trade restrictions and other forms of sanctions).
A higher ratio of government expenditure to GDP reduces the number of deaths from both floods and tropical cyclones.
For floods, there is some evidence that higher school enrolment rates are associated with an increased number of deaths, although this is not a consistent finding across model specifications.
higher credit-to-GDP ratios appear to be associated with an increased number of lives lost, although again for flood events this finding is not consistently significant across model specifications.
10% rise in GDP per capita reduces economic damages from flood events.
